captions.text: Would mathematics exist if people didn't?

Since ancient times, 
mankind has hotly debated

whether mathematics 
was discovered or invented.

Did we create mathematical concepts to
help us understand the universe around us,

or is math the native language of
the universe itself,

existing whether we find 
its truths or not?

Are numbers, polygons 
and equations truly real,

or merely ethereal representations
of some theoretical ideal?

The independent reality of math has
some ancient advocates.

The Pythagoreans of 5th Century Greece
believed numbers were both
living entities and universal principles.

They called the number one, "the monad,"
the generator of all other numbers
and source of all creation.
Numbers were active agents in nature.

Plato argued mathematical 
concepts were concrete

and as real as the universe itself,
regardless of our knowledge of them.

Euclid, the father of geometry, believed
nature itself

was the physical manifestation
of mathematical laws.

Others argue that while numbers may
or may not exist physically,
mathematical statements definitely don't.

Their truth values are based on rules
that humans created.

Mathematics is thus an invented
logic exercise,

with no existence outside mankind's
conscious thought,

a language of abstract relationships
based on patterns discerned by brains,

built to use those patterns to invent
useful but artificial order from chaos.

One proponent of this sort of idea
was Leopold Kronecker,

a professor of mathematics in 
19th century Germany.

His belief is summed up in 
his famous statement:

"God created the natural numbers,
all else is the work of man."

During mathematician
David Hilbert's lifetime,

there was a push to establish mathematics
as a logical construct.

Hilbert attempted to axiomatize all
of mathematics,
as Euclid had done with geometry.

He and others who attempted this saw
mathematics as a deeply philosophical game
but a game nonetheless.

Henri Poincaré, one of the father's of
non-Euclidean geometry,

believed that the existence of 
non-Euclidean geometry,

dealing with the non-flat surfaces of 
hyperbolic and elliptical curvatures,

proved that Euclidean geometry, the
long standing geometry of flat surfaces,
was not a universal truth,

but rather one outcome of using one
particular set of game rules.

But in 1960, Nobel Physics laureate
Eugene Wigner

coined the phrase, "the unreasonable 
effectiveness of mathematics,"

pushing strongly for the idea that
mathematics is real
and discovered by people.

Wigner pointed out that many purely
mathematical theories

developed in a vacuum, often with no view
towards describing any physical phenomena,

have proven decades 
or even centuries later,
to be the framework necessary to explain

how the universe
has been working all along.

For instance, the number theory of British
mathematician Gottfried Hardy,

who had boasted that none of his work
would ever be found useful

in describing any phenomena
in the real world,
helped establish cryptography.

Another piece of his purely
theoretical work

became known as the Hardy-Weinberg
law in genetics,
and won a Nobel prize.

And Fibonacci stumbled 
upon his famous sequence

while looking at the growth of an 
idealized rabbit population.

Mankind later found the sequence
everywhere in nature,

from sunflower seeds
and flower petal arrangements,
to the structure of a pineapple,

even the branching of bronchi
in the lungs.

Or there's the non-Euclidean work of
Bernhard Riemann in the 1850s,

which Einstein used in the model for
general relativity a century later.
Here's an even bigger jump:

mathematical knot theory, first developed
around 1771
to describe the geometry of position,

was used in the late 20th century
to explain how DNA unravels itself
during the replication process.

It may even provide key explanations
for string theory.

Some of the most influential 
mathematicians and scientists

of all of human history
have chimed in on the issue as well,
often in surprising ways.

So, is mathematics an 
invention or a discovery?

Artificial construct or
universal truth?

Human product or
natural, possibly divine, creation?

These questions are so deep the debate
often becomes spiritual in nature.

The answer might depend on the specific
concept being looked at,

but it can all feel like a
distorted zen koan.

If there's a number of trees in a forest,
but no one's there to count them,
does that number exist?

title: Is math discovered or invented? - Jeff Dekofsky

comments.author: CornerrecordZ

comments.text:
logical relationships are discovered, while vocabulary is invented to 
describe those relationships. math includes both relationships and 
vocabulary, so math is both discovered and invented. 
math is not a single thing, its a system, partially based on discovered 
logic, and partially based on inventive creativity. if you separate it into 
parts, classifying each part becomes easy.

a lot of silly philosophical questions come from false dichotomies, and 
trying to organize groups into categories only fit for individual parts, 
for example:
is a hammer a work of art, or a functional tool? a hammer is both. the 
color choice of the handle is art, while the balance of weight and shape of 
the head is designed for a purpose. 

if you can't tell if something is a problem or a choice, or you can't tell 
how something fits in with a taxonomy, than you should probably break the 
subject down into individual components before classifying things. 

so math is a mix of discovered and invented components. ﻿

comments.author: Sarthak Bhalerao

comments.text:
Mathematics is ultimately a tool to help humans recognize patterns and 
relationships between quantitative objects. In short, math is how we put 
the world in human terms; attributing symbols to large amounts of something 
and using more symbols to figure out relationships. Math is completely 
invented and its principles are constantly being changed/altered as time 
goes on. Contrary to popular belief, math isn't perfect. As we learn more 
we invent newer, better ways of interoperating physical object 
relationships. 

For example, numbers don't exist independent of what they quantify. Every 
number in an equation counts for something even in super abstract 
Mathematics. 

All in all, Math, not the objects/phenomena they quantify, is completely 
invented.﻿

comments.author: Anna Roland

comments.text:
I think of the mathematical language, the same way I do the spoken 
language. Humans invented language in order to communicated with one 
another. The universe didn't create languages. Therefore we were free to 
decide what words meant what. We invented the ways to structure words and 
sentence. Every language has properties that you must learn, to learn that 
language. There are many different ways to say the word "hello". You can 
translate "hello" to other languages. Invention are our way of manipulating 
the nature around us. We didn't invent air, but we built something that 
could work with it to fly. We didn't invent the atom, but we can make 
compounds using the properties of atoms. Inventions use the properties of 
nature to suit our needs. We can't create those properties. The properties 
of a photon should be the same for all other photons in the universe. 



Once we defined what the number 1 was and what it was worth, all other 
numbers had to follow it. Math as we know it had to be built on what 1 
meant and what it was worth. If we change the meaning and value of 1, our 
mathematical concepts fall apart. If an alien species invented what "WE" 
call numbers and gave them values, they would have to build mathematical 
concepts based on how they define numbers. In fact, they probably wouldn't 
even call what we call numbers, numbers. How they quantify their world is 
irreverent. The value of 1 in any alien species, should be translatable to 
other mathematical language. The value of 1 should mean the same thing to 
every alien mathematical language if translated to native tongue. Exactly 
how "hello" can be translate to other languages. If we invented math to 
translate or understand how our universe works, then other alien species 
what have to be able to do that same.



Whether math is a discover or a invention lies in whether you can get your 
idea of math to work with nature. If you can't get your math to work with 
the laws of nature, then your version of math is useless. Math has to be 
able to predict how nature works. It must explain how we view nature. You 
have to be able to predict the nature around you with math, regardless of 
where you are in the universe. An alien species would have to obey the laws 
of nature just like we do. Since we can't change the laws of nature, all we 
can do is translate it using math. Because of that, math just might be a 
discovery, rather than a invention. If you could invented math, you would 
also have to invented the laws of nature. And math must explain nature.

The real question is whether our not nature has only one translation.

In my opinion, math was discovered by man because we think.﻿
comments.author: Wretched Egg, Shiro 史郎

comments.author: Azureim

comments.text:
+Vinay Seth I believe that religion has indeed influenced all humankind, 
atheists and religious people alike. The good, the bad, the scientists, the 
architects, the dictators. We can only imagine (and I refer here to John 
Lennon) a world with no religion. How would this world look like? 

Religion had a strong influence on all people, no doubt, but so did honey. 
Or alcohol. Or pet dogs and cats. Or vegetables. Or other people. Or books, 
If I may name a better
and less ironic example. Should any influence be mentioned? 

Perhaps I could make the context of my personal disapproval of God being 
mentioned in an educational video even clearer. I come from a country where 
religion is being pushed into education, science and has a growing 
influence in the government. It is forced down the throats of my fellow 
citizens by the mass media, by the priests and by the creationist governors.

I am all for the freedom of religion. But as long as one keeps his religion 
to himself and we can live in a peaceful and secular world of science and 
reason. And when it comes to technology, education and development (those 
things that TED stands for), I can see more of a negative influence of 
religion, rather than a positive one, no matter how much I try. 

Consider those science books that have been banned by the inquisition 
during history. The books that have been burned. The libraries that have 
been burned. The free thinkers thathave been burned. Was that an influence 
of religion? Or perhaps this led to an artificial lack of influence that 
could have otherwise brought up more scientists and educated men. 

We know a lot of dark facts about the dark ages and the religious wars 
waged at those times that have never stopped and continue up to this very 
day. In some countries people are killed for having the wrong religion or 
having no religion at all. Or they are killed for having a different sexual 
orientation, because a holy book says that is a sin against God. Or they 
are killed or sent to prison for drawing or saying something that some 
religious people do not approve. Or for art that some religious people do 
not like. Must I name these countries or do we all understand what I am 
talking about?

Some of these countries are somehow at good diplomatic terms with other 
powerful countries that claim to be secular. Possibly one that you live in. 
Because we are thought to respectall religions. We are thought that 
religions are important and good influences, not a source of prejudice, 
discrimination and violence. So when I see that something as irrational and 
dangerous as religion becomes entangled with beautiful and wondrous science 
in an educational video I can't help to feel as if someone drew a swastika 
on a painting by Isaac Levitan.
comments.author: Azureim

comments.text:
+Azureim
Yes I have seen the Feynman interview you're referring to. And I get your 
point now that you articulate it that way.
See, I'm a visual artist just to give you a background. And I've never had 
anything to do with religion. I declared myself to be an atheist at about 
the age of six but I no longer feel the need to identify with either 
religion or the lack of it thereof.
I'm confounded today when I come to know in my college lectures that some 
of the most influential thinkers right up till the last century came from a 
religious upbringing.
You seem to have a pragmatic attitude- and that's fine- but how do you 
explain something like architecture being influenced by a methodology in 
philosophy called deconstruction, which was the brainchild of Derrida- a 
person who underwent rigorous religious instruction in his childhood (which 
heavily influenced his thinking, by the way)?
What I'm trying to get at - and this video too- is that the motivation to 
do something can come from both pragmatic and purely philosophical 
pursuits- marrying the two mentalities in an educational video like this 
does no harm to the idea discussed, rather makes it accessible to people 
with different bents of mind.
comments.author: Vinay Seth

comments.text:
+Vinay Seth dude, since you started judging my personality, let me tell you 
that personally I am a scientist. I have a Ph.D in computational biology 
and I studied philosophy including Kant for 2 years at the university, with 
excellent grades on this subject. So here is my educated oppinion: Kant has 
nothing to do with physics OR relativity in the physical sense. It's great 
to have an open mind, but if you open your mind to bullshit like 
metaphysics your brains will fall out. Methaphysics is like astrology, a 
bunch of unproven speculation. Same thing with theology. So please don't 
insult the mind of a scientist by comparing biology and physics to mythical 
nonsense.

I am not surprised that philosophers that publish in the "Polish journal of 
philosophy" are more than happy to steal the discovery of a great physicist 
and attribute it to their field (as they have done many times before). They 
have done nothing for our scientific advancement. What they do is they brag 
about "how important philosophy is" but bring nothing of importance to the 
table. Another great physicist Richard Faynman said, I quote: "Philosophy 
is bullshit". And I am not taking this out of context. You should google 
this phrase with Richard Faynmans name and check out his reasoning. I hope 
you are open minded enough to consider the oppinion of an actual scientist 
(a physicist!) as well.
comments.author: Azureim

comments.text:
+Azureim Dude do you even know about the theories you're talking about and 
the insights that were needed to get to them? Einstein couldn't have come 
up with his theories had he not read Kant- you can see Kant's reasoning 
very well in his work. All that philosophers have done throughout ages is 
spatialize and temporalize ideas- you know what Einstein did? He 
temporalized space itself! Do you know what a brilliant move that is? No 
you don't- because you don't possess the open-mindedness to consider 
thought-experiments to be a series of games- be they in metaphysics, 
theology, biology etc. In order to get to his breakthrough, it was 
necessary for Einstein to engage with ideas before him. And yes, I have 
read a bit about Kant's work- though I must admit I haven't read the 
original text. In case you're interested in seriously knowing about Kant's 
influence on Einstein- here is something you can read, written by 
researchers and not close-minded people like you: 
http://www.academia.edu/248944/The_Kantian_Grounding_of_Einstein_s_Worldview_I_The_Early_Influence_of_Kant_s_System_of_Perspectives

comments.author: A Whether Moments Poet

comments.text:
Mathematics, in its current state, is derived from certain properties of 
simple functions ( +, -, x, /) and other properties such as the 
combinative, associative, and other properties of algebra that have led us 
to our current maths. I believe that there are many different ways to 
describe the universe, or different ways of counting, such as different 
basses  ( binary, trinary..), or different sets (quatrains, octernians) 
that yield different formulas and equations. I'me sure that there are evan 
more number systems out there that we haven't Evan thought of yet.

In summary, We picked a commutative, associative, distributive base 10 
number system for our maths, when we could easily have chosen a different 
one. In this sense, we created our mathematics.﻿

comments.text:
Would mathematics exist if people didn't? Did we create mathematical

comments.author: c.s. briar

comments.text:
I would argue discovered, but I wonder how much this really matters. I am 
very philosophical, but I'm trying to imagine what would change if EVERYONE 
thought one way, or if EVERYONE thought the other.

Obviously the vast majority of people don't give a fuck about this kind of 
stuff, but if somehow hypothetically they cared just enough to have an 
opinion, I'm not sure anything would change. The only thing I can think of 
is unlikely and even more philosophical, involving how some people view 
existence and their version of God. It's bad to self-diagnose, but in ways 
I think my discovery of the concept of determinism must have affected my 
outlook on life, even if I can't see exactly how. Taking that a step 
further, I only see this debate affecting people with decent understanding 
of math/logic having an existential crisis.

But maybe the debate does matter. Maybe it will push future mathematicians 
in the right direction. I'm open-minded to a higher level/language of 
understanding the universe, one that makes advanced calculus look like a 2 
year old struggling to form a proper sentence. I'm thinking something like 
Interstellar, but maybe a little more well defined.﻿

comments.author: Shantanu Shekhar

comments.text:
People invented a system for notating mathematics, but we didn't invent the 
mathematical properties themselves.  It's sort of like how we invented the 
word "tree," but we didn't invent trees, or how we invented a method for 
creating and using fire, but we didn't invent fire.

Imagine if we arbitrarily decided that pi (technically not a "natural" 
number) were some other number than what it is, 2.4, for example.  Later, 
you're using this number to calculate how large of a fence you would need 
to completely enclose a circular yard.  The result is that you would fail 
to completely surround the yard, because pi is what it is, regardless of 
what we say it is.

As for curved surfaces, this does not result in new laws of mathematics, 
just new variables affecting the outcome of the same mathematics.  Angles 
differ on curved surfaces, because the curve is part of the equation.  
Compare this scenario:  Suppose I say two plus two equals four, then 
someone says that if the equation only works if the first two were alone.  
If a third item were present, before the two more were added, the result 
would be five.  This would hardly prove that two plus two equals five in 
certain cases, because the one extra item would change the starting 
values.  Adding an extra item to an addition problem is not much different 
from adding an extra curve to a geometry problem.  You still use the same 
math, just with another variable to consider.﻿
comments.author: Shawn Ravenfire

comments.text:
+Shawn Ravenfire
 +blykgod made a valid point. The value of pi didn't have to be 3.14....... 
had we calibrated our mathematical scale differently. For example, its 
value would have been entirely different in binary (base 2), duodecimal 
(base 12), etc. It is quite possible that the whole world would have been 
using different numbering systems had it not been for the 'invention' of 
zero, which made numbering system so much easier (it is much more intuitive 
than using roman numerals, and hence became the standard across the world). 

Pi is the ratio of circumference of a circle to its diameter. The physical 
manifestation, the circle itself is real, but the equation of the circle, 
the concepts of radius, circumference, even the name circle (which has been 
defined by english, an invented language), are our manner of interpreting 
the reality.

As pointed out in the video, mathematics is extremely efficient in 
understanding the world, almost to the point where it may seem that it was 
meant to be the way we understand it now (that it was something predefined 
and we found it, not invented it). However, mathematics has evolved over 
years, and it is quite possible for an intelligent species to invent a 
language which is as highly effective as maths. Also, I don't know what 
you're trying to prove with the last paragraph.

comments.text:
imho, math as we know it is discovered.
We may have invented a language to describe math, but the concepts 
themselves are things that we find out.
If Pythagoras had never stated (something to the effect of) Χ^2 + Ψ^2 = 
Ω^2, wouldn't it still hold true? If someone had come in later on and said 
that a^2 + b^2 = c^2, wouldn't it mean the exact same thing, but with 
different symbols? 
These concepts are universal, but the language used to describe them is 
varied.﻿

comments.author: redge fleming

comments.text:
I feel like people are getting caught in the semantics of what 
"mathematics." If you are defining "mathematics" as the systematic method, 
or science, of understanding reality using numbers, then of course, it is 
an invention; however, if you are defining "mathematics" as a numerical 
pattern that is existent in reality, then mankind has discovered it. An 
example: physics did not invent gravity. Gravity has always been a 
naturally occurring phenomenon; physics, or "the science of matter, energy, 
motion, and force," merely allowed human beings to discover and learn about 
gravity. So, are you defining "mathematics" as a science or a naturally 
occurring phenomenon? I personally believe in the reality of math that is 
existent regardless of man's understanding.

On another note, I'm bothered when people, upon observing the beauty of a 
natural phenomenon and appreciating it in awe, give science the credit for 
the amazement and not phenomenon itself by claiming something along the 
lines of "I love science." Sure, science allowed you to discover and 
understand that amazing thing which you now experience, but it is the very 
reality of the universe that creates your wonder. In other words, that 
phenomenon has always been that amazing even before you realized it from 
your scientific understanding. If you discover a beautiful phenomenon such 
as a rainbow for the first time, don't go, "I love science"; instead, say 
"I love rainbows" because the rainbow has always been beautiful whether or 
not you knew about it and it is the rainbow which invoked amazement within 
you, not science. Another example that might be easier to understand: it's 
like when you realize just how amazing your spouse is and think, "dating is 
wonderful!" No, it's not dating, or the process of discovering your spouse, 
which caused your appreciation; it was your spouse. You should think, "my 
spouse is wonderful" because he/she is! Your spouse has always been 
wonderful whether or not you met him/her through dating (I know people 
change, but just go with my example here). Your discovery of your spouse 
did not didn't create the wonderfulness within your spouse; it merely 
allowed you to experience it. In other words, science didn't create the 
amazing reality of life, and therefore, your discovery should not be 
credited for the awe induced by reality. ﻿
